A 30-year-old married man is suffering from scabies. The doctor who treated his illness disclosed the information to his wife. What is this an example of?

A 30-year-old previously healthy male presents to the emergency department with a fever. He reports feeling generally unwell for the past three days, with associated chills and sweating. On examination, his temperature is 39.2°C (102.5°F), heart rate 100 bpm, respiratory rate 18 breaths/min, blood pressure 120/80 mmHg, and oxygen saturation 98% on room air. He appears tired but is alert and oriented. His physical examination is unremarkable, with no focal signs of infection. What is the most appropriate next step in the evaluation of this patient?

answers.option: Order a complete blood count (CBC) with differential
Start antipyretic medication and reassess after 24 hours

question: A 31-year-old female presents with a painless skin rash behind her right ear. On examination, it is a patch-like hypopigmented area with reduced sensation and well-demarcated borders. What is the most likely diagnosis?

answers.option: Squamous cell carcinoma of the skin

question: A 33-year-old woman presents to the outpatient department with a three-day history of a white, fishy vaginal discharge. She has no history of sexually transmitted disease, post-coital bleeding, or dysuria. On speculum examination, there is a milky fluid in the posterior fornix but no signs of inflammation. What is the most likely diagnosis?
A 34-year-old intravenous drug abuser comes with bloody diarrhea for 3 months. Which of the following is the most common protozoan causing bloody diarrhea?

A 34-year-old male, farmer by profession presents to the outpatient clinic with vague right-sided abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting. Laboratory and radiological workups reveal hydatid cyst disease of the liver. This is his second recurrence in 2 years. What is the treatment for this patient?

A 34-year-old presents with abdominal pain, bloating, nausea, and vomiting for the past few days. A complete blood count reveals eosinophilia. Small bowel obstruction is present. A nasogastric (NG) tube is inserted. Which of the following drugs is the most appropriate?

A 35-year-old diabetic patient presents to the outpatient department with complaints of fever associated with rigors and chills, and increased frequency of urine. She also complains of pain during micturition. Other systemic findings are unremarkable. What is the most accurate test for diagnosis?

A 35-year-old female patient presented with fever, chills, sweating, and headache, weakness, presumptively diagnosed as "viral syndrome." Later, the patient deteriorated with an altered level of consciousness, severe anemia, renal failure, and multisystem failure. Blood samples were sent for lab investigations including malarial parasites. Crescent or sausage (banana) shaped gametocytes are characteristic features of which of the plasmodium species?

A 35-year-old female presented with fever, chills, sweating, weakness, and headache, presumptively diagnosed as 'viral syndrome'. The patient's condition later deteriorated with altered level of consciousness, severe anemia, renal failure, and multisystem failure. Blood sample investigation showed malarial parasite. Crescent or sausage (banana) shaped gametocytes are a characteristic of which plasmodium species?

A 35-year-old male comes to the outpatient department (OPD) with complaints of high-grade fever associated with chills, nausea, vomiting. The doctor diagnoses him with the case of malaria caused by Plasmodium falciparum. Which of the following is the life-threatening complication of this type of malaria?
A 35-year-old male consults to physician after being bitten by a stranded dog within 24 hours. What post-exposure prophylaxis regime will the doctor offer him after local wound care or cleaning?

answers.option: 20 IU/kg human rabies immunoglobulin (HRIG) plus 5 doses of 1 ml human diploid cell vaccine (HDCV)
20 IU/kg human rabies immunoglobulin (HRIG) plus 3 doses of 1 ml human diploid cell vaccine (HDCV)
10 IU/kg human rabies immunoglobulin (HRIG) plus 5 doses of 1 ml human diploid cell vaccine (HDCV)
5 doses of 1 ml human diploid cell vaccine (HDCV); intramuscular (I/M)

question: A 35-year-old male presented to the outpatient department with a prolonged history of fever and weight loss. On clinical examination, there is lymphadenopathy and hepatosplenomegaly. Complete blood count (CBC) shows pancytopenia. He is suspected of visceral leishmaniasis. Which of the following investigations is used for definitive diagnosis of visceral leishmaniasis?

answers.option: Identification of amastigote in macrophages in tissue sample

question: A 35-year-old male presented with a one-and-half-year history of pruritus, swelling, and pain involving the distal extremities and the ears. Physical examinations revealed nonpitting edema of the ears, bilateral loss of eyelashes, and ill-defined somewhat dusky, hyperpigmented patches scattered diffusely and symmetrically on his extremities with sparing of the trunk and neck. Histopathology of the skin biopsy demonstrated granulomatous infiltrates, with perineural and perivascular involvement, and a large number of acid-fast bacilli on the Ziehle Neelsen stain. What would be the diagnosis?

A 35-year-old male presents to the clinic with hypopigmented lesions on his limbs and back. He has been treated with antifungals but did not heal. He has also developed polyarthritis with edema. He has thick cutaneous nerves, radial, ulnar, and tibial nerves. The nerves are painful and tender. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 35-year-old man presented to the skin specialist with complaints of skin lesions on his face and arms for six months. The lesions are hypopigmented and lack sensation. On examination, the skin over the brows and ears has thickened, and there are nodules on the face. He was diagnosed as having leprosy. Which of the following statements is correct?

answers.option: Lepromin skin testing is positive in lepromatous types of leprosy
Tuberculin skin test is positive for any type of leprosy
The lepromin skin test is positive in the tuberculoid type of leprosy
There is no role for cell-mediated immunity, but granulomas are usually absent
Its clinical presentation is not classical

question: A 35-year-old man presents to the emergency department with complaints of fever, malaise, and cough associated with severe pain in muscles and joints. His CBC report shows leucopenia and thrombocytopenia. The serological test report shows NS1 antigen-positive. The patient is suffering from which one of the following infectious diseases?

A 36-year-old male presented to the emergency department with a fever lasting for three days, accompanied by mild abdominal pain. Upon examination, he exhibited a fever of 103°F and jaundice, along with a palpable spleen. A peripheral blood film revealed the presence of trophozoites of Plasmodium falciparum. What is the preferred treatment for uncomplicated falciparum malaria?

A 36-year-old male presents to the outpatient department with complaints of fever, weakness , weight loss and massive splenomegaly. He is suspected to be infected by Leishmania donovani, which is the cause of kala azar (visceral leishmaniasis). Which system of the body is affected by this infection?

A 36-year-old man presented to the emergency room with complaints of fever and mild abdominal pain for 3 days. On examination, he is febrile (103°F) with jaundice and a palpable spleen. Plasmodium falciparum trophozoites are visible in the peripheral film. In cases of uncomplicated falciparum malaria, which treatment is recommended?

A 38-year-old male presents to the outpatient department with complaints of generalized weakness and chronic diarrhea. He has had excessive weight loss over the past few months. He gives a history of drug abuse. Suspecting HIV, which screening test should be advised?

A 4-year-old boy came to the outpatient department with fever for fifteen days. On examination, he was lethargic and pale, temperature was 101 °F, heart rate was 110 beats/min, and respiratory rate was 30 breaths/min. Abdominal examination showed hepatosplenomegaly. Rest of the examination was unremarkable. What is the most appropriate investigation to reach the diagnosis?

A 4-year-old child is brought to the clinic with a complaint of diarrhea for the past 4 days. On examination, the child is irritable and has sunken eyes. What is the appropriate classification according to IMNCI protocol?

A 40-year-old farmer is brought to the emergency after collapsing in his home. After regaining consciousness, he complains of right hypochondrial pain and on imaging, calcified cysts are observed in his liver. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 40-year-old female presents with complaints of purulent vaginal discharge and intermenstrual bleeding. Gram staining of endocervical screening revealed the presence of gram-negative diplococci. What would be the diagnosis?

A 40-year-old male is bitten by a sandfly and has presented to the outpatient department with an ulcerated red papule. The doctor suspects infection with Leishmania tropica. Which of the following is found in the skin lesion smear for the diagnosis?

A 40-year-old male presents with dyspnea, cyanosis, and tachycardia. He is a chain smoker and there is a ventilation-perfusion mismatch on the V/Q scan. Which of the following lung complications can result as a result of systemic inflammatory response syndrome (SIRS)?

A 41-year-old man, with a history of HIV/AIDS, presents to the outpatient clinic with worsening dyspnea and cough for the last 5 days. The cough is non-productive and associated with a low-grade fever. A CD4+ count is ordered and is found to be 160 cells/mm3. Bronchoalveolar lavage, treated with methenamine silver staining, shows disc-shaped yeast cells. Which of the following organisms is most likely linked to this man's condition?

A 43-year-old man presented with a 3-day history of peri-umbilical pain which had localized to the right iliac fossa by the time he attended hospital. He described the pain as sharp, constant, and aggravated by movement. Examination findings revealed a soft abdomen with tenderness and guarding in the right iliac fossa. The physician suspected him of acute appendicitis. Which one of the following would be raised in acute appendicitis?

A 45-year-old female had fever and chills. Malarial parasite was positive on MP-ICT. She was treated with artemisinin based combination therapy. She went to donate blood after one session. The blood bank refused donation because she had gametocytes on peripheral smear. She is worried and wants a retreatment. What should be the next step of management?

answers.option: Repeat peripheral smear from well reputed laboratory
Needs long term prophylaxis to clear the gametocytes
A different antimalarial drug should be used
Repeat course of artemisinin based combination therapy (ACT)

question: A 45-year-old male comes to his doctor with the chief complaints of fever, night sweats, and increased episodes of diarrhea during the past month. He has lost 30 pounds over the past 4 months. On physical exam, he has oral thrush and cervical lymphadenopathy. The patient has a contact history as well. The clinician has a strong suspicion of human immune deficiency virus (HIV) infection. Which of the following is the confirmatory test for HIV infection?

A 45-year-old male is suffering from high-grade fever, severe body ache, and bleeding from the nose and mouth since the last 2 days. He consulted his general physician but the prescribed medicines did not give any relief. He works as a butcher and handles alive animals. His complete blood count shows hemoglobin 14.5 g/dL, white blood cells 1200/mm³, platelet count 37000/mm³. What is the best treatment option for him?

answers.option: IV antibiotics to prevent bacterial infection
IV domperidone or any other prokinetic agent

question: A 45-year-old man presented to the outpatient department with fever, constipation, and abdominal tenderness. Blood culture showed growth of non-lactose fermenting (colorless) gram-negative bacteria on MacConkey's agar and the production of hydrogen sulfide gas on TSI agar. What is the probable diagnosis?

A 45-year-old patient presents with right-sided focal fits. History reveals that he is an AIDS (acquired immunodeficiency syndrome) patient. Magnetic resonance imaging shows multiple ring-enhancing lesions in the cortical grey-white matter of the brain. What is the cause of fits?

A 46-year-old female suffers an injury on her foot with a rusty nail while walking barefoot on her lawn. She rushes to the emergency department and seeks medical help. The doctor cleans her wound with normal saline and dresses her wound. Which of the following is most likely to cause an infection in her case?

A 5-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department with uncontrolled muscle spasms and lockjaw. A provisional diagnosis of tetanus is made and appropriate therapy is started. What is the antibiotic therapy for this infection?

A 5-year-old boy was brought to the OPD with complaints of water-filled blisters on his whole body including trunk and both upper and lower extremities. He also complained of severe itching along with fever ad malaise. On clinical grounds doctor suspected him to be suffering with varicella. A presumptive diagnosis of his condition can be made by which of the following techniques?

A 50-year-old female sustained injury from rusty metal on her right finger while cleaning. She is cautious and seeks emergency treatment. You washed her wound with normal saline and dressed it. Which infection is she at risk of acquiring?

A 50-year-old female while cleaning her home sustained a rusty metal injury on her right finger. She is very cautious and came to seek treatment at the emergency department. You have washed her wound with normal saline and dressed it. Which of the following infections she is at risk of acquiring?
A 50-year-old male HIV patient is being evaluated for AIDS-defining diseases. Which of the following is not an AIDS-defining illness?

A 50-year-old male patient enters the emergency department with a profuse, productive cough. The infection control nurse instructs the patient's attendant to take their patient to the separate waiting area at the corner. Which of the following is the segregation of patients before they enter the usual waiting room?

A 50-year-old male presented in OPD with hypopigmented lesions on his hands and forearms, especially the elbows. He also complains of loss of sensation in these lesions. On examination, there is a loss of pinprick sensation in the affected areas and his ulnar nerve is palpable under the elbow. How would you confirm your diagnosis?

A 55-year-old male presents with fever, weight loss, and cough with hemoptysis for the past 2 weeks. His sputum is acid-fast bacillus (AFB) smear-positive. What is the likely diagnosis of this patient?

A 6-day-old neonate is brought to the pediatric emergency with a history of fits and refusal to take feed. The fits are more severe on exposure to light and excessive sound. The neonate was delivered at home. What is the causative organism?

A 6-year-old boy is brought to the outpatient department with complaints of high-grade fever (102°F) for 4 days. On physical examination, the child is febrile with cropped vesicles on the trunk and scattered scabbed lesions. Which of the following infections is the most likely diagnosis?

A 6-year-old boy presents with fever, malaise, cough, running nose and conjunctivitis. The boy does not receive any childhood vaccination. On examination, his temperature is 102.7 F and there are white spots on a red base close to his second molar teeth. He also has a non-pruritic, maculopapular rash on his face, behind his ears, and spreading to his chest. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 68-year-old man has had dyspnea for 3 years without any history of cough and fever. He worked in coal mines for the last 10 years. A chest x-ray shows prominent interstitial markings with nodules. Which one of the following is an identifying feature of his condition?

A 7-year-old boy is brought to the outpatient department with a complaint of fever and vesicular rashes all over the body. The vesicles appear in bunches and some are in the healing phase. There is a history of sore throat and cough too. What is the long-term complication of the condition at a later age?

A 7-year-old child has had 6 to 8 small volume stools daily for the last 3 days. The stools do not contain any blood or mucus. On examination, no signs of dehydration are noticed. What is the most likely diagnosis?
A 7-year-old girl presents to the office with a complaint of fever for the last 10 days. She also developed a red, spotty rash over her abdomen 2 days ago. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A blood culture shows the growth of non-lactose fermenting (colorless), gram-negative bacteria on MacConkey's agar and the production of hydrogen sulfide gas on TSI agar. Which of the following is the most likely organism?
A child has a vesicular rash over the face and trunk, along with a high-grade fever. 2 weeks ago the child went on a trip where another child had similar symptoms. What is the diagnosis?

A child has not been going to school because he has a vesicular rash over the face and trunk, along with a high-grade fever. 2 weeks ago the child went on a cruise where a boy had similar symptoms. What is the causative organism of this child's condition?

A child is brought to the clinic for having loose stools with a frequency of 20 per day. On examination, normal skin turgor and no sunken eyes are found. When water is offered, he drinks it eagerly. What is the classification according to IMNCI?
A child is brought to the clinic for medical consultation with complaints of painful swelling of the parotid gland, fever and difficulty in swallowing. What would be the most probable diagnosis?

A child is brought to the outpatient department with complaints of fever, and swelling in the jaw. The mother further adds the swelling is painful when the child drinks citrus fruit juices. On examination, swelling is noticed to be of parotid gland enlargement. What is the child suffering from?

A child is brought to the pediatrics clinic for evaluation of diarrhea. His systemic findings are unremarkable except that he has less weight and height for his age. It is found that he has malabsorption syndrome. What is the causative agent in this case?

A child presents to the outpatient department with complaints of fever, fatigue, and severe itching in the rash. On examination, the papulovesicular rash is seen on the child's trunk and extremities. Which stain or smear can be used for the diagnosis of the organism involved?
A child presents with high-grade fever, runny nose, and cough. White lesions are found on the oral mucosa. What is the pathognomonic sign for measles?
A diabetic woman came to the clinic with the complaint of vaginal itch. Which of the following is the most likely cause of her condition?

A dying female victim of domestic violence recorded her deposition in the hospital, which is under oath and in the presence of the magistrate and accused, regarding the circumstances of her death. Why does a dying deposition carry more weight than a dying declaration?

answers.option: Oath of the dying person is an essential prerequisite
It is recorded in the presence of the accused
Remains valid even after the recovery of the depositor
It is recorded by a magistrate

question: A dying female victim of domestic violence, while in the hospital, recorded her deposition on oath in the presence of a magistrate and the accused, describing the circumstances of her impending death. Why does this deposition carry more legal weight than a dying declaration?

answers.option: It is recorded in the presence of the accused.
The oath of the dying person is an essential prerequisite.
It remains valid even after the recovery of the depositor.
It is recorded by a magistrate.

question: A female patient presents to the clinic with a complaint of purulent vaginal discharge. Gram staining of the discharge reveals gram-negative diplococci. What is the best treatment?
A female patient presents to the gynecology department with a complaint of vaginal discharge. What is the non-infectious cause of vaginal discharge?
A girl got injured with a rusty nail by walking around barefoot. What organism is she at the risk of being affected with?
A girl presents to the outpatient department with lethargy and an ulcer in her right foot. Her laboratory results show hemoglobin 6 mg/dL. What is the cause of her condition?
A greenstick fracture is commonly seen in which of the following?

A health officer has taken up the challenge to eradicate HIV (human immunodeficiency virus). His team identified groups of high-risk individuals. Which of the following high-risk groups should be intervened first?
A histopathologist is evaluating a specimen under a microscope and describes it as 'spiral-shaped, with no gram staining'. Which of the following is the most likely specimen?

A housewife presents to the clinic with severe abdominal pain and diarrhea which started off as watery but now contains blood in it. Laboratory findings show leukocytes and red blood cells in the stool. She denies having eaten any undercooked food in the past week. Which of the following organisms is most likely involved?
A lucid interval is common in which of the following conditions?

A male patient presents with lower abdominal discomfort, flatulence, and occasional diarrhea. A diagnosis of intestinal amebiasis is made, and Entamoeba histolytica is identified in his diarrheal stools. The preferred treatment that he should have received for the initial symptoms (which were indicative of mild-to-moderate disease) is:
A man falls in the washroom and later presents with a high-grade fever. The doctor suspects that he has chronic inflammation. Which of the following are the dominant cells of chronic inflammation?

A man presents to the clinic with the complaint of a thick, yellow, mucoid, and purulent urethral discharge. He has had a new sexual partner for two weeks. Which infections would you consider in this patient?

A man presents to the emergency department of the hospital and is referred to a medicolegal officer due to a suspicious stab wound on his abdomen. However, the clothes he wore had no incision. Which of the following is the best explanation for this man's case?

A man presents to the hospital with an altered level of consciousness two hours after falling in the washroom. He has pinpoint pupils with a pulse of 78 beats per minute, a blood pressure of 180/120 mmHg, and a fever of 107°F despite antipyretics. Sponging is also of no use. What is the most likely cause of fever?

A man presents to the outpatient department with a bite wound on his arm. He has cats and rats in her house. On examination, the bite marks look more likely of a rat. Which of the following animals will not transmit rabies?

A man with a known case of HIV presents to the outpatient department with complaints of fever, weight loss, and fatigue. He is diagnosed with the case of mycobacterium avium complex. What is the treatment used for this patient?

A medical man appeared in the court to record his statement. After recording, he feels that the court might misinterpret his observations, which may likely lead to a miscarriage of justice. What can he do in this scenario to ensure that justice is served right?

A medical officer detects an HIV (human immunodeficiency virus) positive case in the blood bank and searches for the sexual partner of the donor to prevent and treat the disease in the partner. Which process is described here?
A medical worker accidentally gets pricked by a needle used on an HIV-positive patient. What is the risk percentage of him getting an HIV infection?

A middle-aged man presents to the outpatient department with complaints of headache, vomiting, and seizures after he ate undercooked pork. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the brain is carried out, which reveals multiple lesions bilaterally. The doctor diagnosed him with cysticercosis of the brain. Which of the following parasites is responsible for cysticercosis?

A non-governmental organization working to control malaria in flood-affected areas of Pakistan seeks advice from a public health specialist regarding the control and elimination of malaria. Which one of the following options captures the most appropriate advice?

A patient comes to the emergency department with a history of prolonged cough, fever and chest infection. He is diagnosed with a case of tuberculosis after getting confirmation from the report of biopsy. Which one of the following would have been the identifying feature of tuberculosis?

A patient comes to the emergency department with a history of prolonged cough, fever, and chest infection. He is diagnosed with a case of tuberculosis after getting confirmation from the report of the biopsy. What is tuberculosis characterized by?

A patient comes to the emergency department with fever, abdominal cramps, and a history of passing only a small amount of loose stools. Lab findings show mucous, red blood cells, and white blood cells in the stool sample. Which of the following best describes this condition?

A patient had a hypopigmented skin lesion on one side, which progressed to multiple sites. Some of these lesions resolved on their own and then new lesions appeared. He also has anorexia, fever, and weight loss. What is the most likely diagnosis?
A patient has a positive test for salmonella typhi. Which disease is he suffering from?
A patient has worms in their eyes on examination. Which of the following organisms is most likely to cause such a presentation?

A patient is admitted to the hospital for surgery. On the 8th day of admission, they develop fever, dyspnea, and productive cough. A chest X-ray shows consolidations in the right lower lobe. What is the most likely diagnosis?
A patient is admitted to the intensive care unit due to sepsis. He is being mechanically ventilated. What should be the central venous pressure (CVP)?

A patient is brought to the clinic with the complaint of fever, cough, dyspnea, and cyanosis. He also has tachycardia and his blood pressure is 80/60 mmHg. On auscultation, crackles and decreased breath sounds can be heard in the right lower lobe. What is the diagnosis?

A patient presents to the clinic with a complaint of bloody diarrhea. A sorbitol-negative strain of Escherichia coli is found to be the causative agent. Which of the following has caused this condition?

A patient presents to the clinic with a high-grade fever, productive cough, and a runny nose with red eyes. He, later on, notices a maculopapular rash beginning to appear on his forehead. What is the patient most likely suffering from?
A patient presents to the clinic with complaints of cough and chest pain suggestive of pneumonia. He has had a splenectomy. Which of the following gram-positive organisms can be the causative agent?
A patient presents to the emergency room with a cough, runny nose, and red eyes. On examination, koplik spots are found in the buccal mucosa. What is the patient suffering from?

A patient presents to the gynecology department with a lesion in a genital area. On examination, it is found to be a sexually transmitted genital ulcerative disease in which irregular margins of a lesion are seen. The patient is also seen to have tender lymphadenopathy and diagnosis of chancroid is made. Chancroid is caused by which organism?

A patient presents to the outpatient department with a history of cough for more than three weeks, night sweats, loss of appetite, and fever. The physician advises a chest x-ray, sputum culture, and Zeihl-nelson staining of the sputum. He was diagnosed as a case of tuberculosis. Which one of the following is an identifying feature of tuberculosis?

A patient presents to the outpatient department with abdominal pain, relative bradycardia, and a fever that started as low-grade but has been persistently increasing for days. He also has salmon-colored spots on his trunk. What is the most likely diagnosis?
A patient starts having diarrhea after taking antibiotics during his hospital stay. Which organism is most likely involved?

A patient who was diagnosed with AIDS (acquired immune deficiency syndrome) and tuberculosis (TB) 2 years back is admitted for surgery for appendicitis. He is compliant with HIV medications. He completed anti-TB therapy and now his chest x-ray is clear with no pulmonary infiltrates and no bacteria in his sputum. What precautions should be taken?

answers.option: Single room with contact and airborne precautions

question: A patient with AIDS has a CD4 count of 45/µL. He is being maintained on a 3-drug regimen of indinavir, didanosine, and zidovudine. Which of the following drugs may cause an episode of acute pancreatitis?

A patient with a broken leg is being transported to the hospital in an ambulance. While crossing a signal, another vehicle unexpectedly collides with the ambulance, leading to the patient's death. In legal terms, which of the following best describes the cause of death?
A patient with a history of AIDs and tuberculosis 2 years back is admitted for the surgery of appendicitis. What precautions should be taken?
A person having mucopurulent urethral discharge is diagnosed with gonorrhea. Which of the following will be shown on culture?

answers.option: Gram positive cocci in grape like cluster
Gram negative cocci in grape like cluster

question: A person presents to the clinic with bloody diarrhea and is diagnosed with intestinal amebiasis caused by Entamoeba histolytica. Which of the following is true for this organism?
A person was bitten by a mosquito and later developed malaria. Which of the following does the mosquito inject when it takes a blood meal?
A person was walking barefoot in their yard and stubbed their toe on a rusted nail. Which of the following organisms is most likely to infect the injury?

A person, before going on a trip to a malaria-endemic area, takes prophylaxis for chloroquine-resistant falciparum malaria but nonetheless develops Plasmodium vivax malaria. Which of the following drugs did he most likely take?
A person, while traveling, carries a disease with him from an area where it is highly prevalent, to a place in which it does not normally occur. Which of the following terms is used for it?

A physician is interested in performing entomological testing on the mosquito which is an important vector for transmitting viral fevers in Pakistan. Which of the following mosquitoes is of interest to him?

A premature neonate suffered respiratory distress and was given an antibiotic 100 mg/kg/day orally. Over the next two days his condition worsened, he became dull, stopped feeding, and developed abdominal distention and an ashen gray appearance. Which is the most likely antibiotic given to him?

A premature neonate suffered respiratory distress and was given an antibiotic 100 mg/kg/day orally. Over the next two days, his condition worsened. He became dull, stopped feeding, and developed abdominal distention, and an ashen grey appearance. Which is the most likely antibiotic given to him?
A severe outbreak of bloody diarrhea is seen in a psychiatric hospital within the past 1 week. What is the most common agent implicated in such cases?

A student is in charge of the urogenital system and needs to decide who should be screened for gonorrhea. Out of the following options, which of the following groups of people does not need to be screened?
A swimmer developed diarrhea and abdominal cramping after the swimming competition. Which organism is the cause of his symptoms?
A teenager is hospitalized with a history of a dog bite 2 weeks ago. He is found to be anxious, irritable, and drooling at the mouth. What is the appropriate treatment for him?

answers.option: Pass a nasogastric tube for feeding and medications
Provide a comfort care in a quiet environment
Pass an endotracheal tube for ventilation

question: A traveler in a geographical region where chloroquine-resistant Plasmodium falciparum is endemic used a drug for prophylaxis but nevertheless developed a severe attack of P vivax malaria. The drug taken for chemoprophylaxis was probably:
A urea breath test is performed on a patient of which of the following conditions?
A very effective vaccine for which of the following is available to prevent diarrhea in children?
A woman is admitted for an elective/non-emergency procedure. Which type of consent should be taken before the operation?

A young child presented to the outpatient department with a history of low-grade fever, loss of appetite, and lethargy. Blood culture is positive for Salmonella typhi. Salmonella typhi is transmitted by which of the following routes?

A young female is brought to the emergency room with severe abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting for the past 2 hours. She had a meal consisting of rice and curry at a local restaurant 3 hours prior to the onset of her symptoms. What is the likely etiologic agent?

A young female presents to the outpatient department with greenish, foul-smelling vaginal discharge. A wet mount shows pear-shaped trophozoites with a jerky motion. Which of the following is the most likely organism involved?

A young male comes to the physician with complaints of high-grade fever and swelling in front of both ears causing difficulty in mouth opening. On examination, bilateral painful parotid enlargement was there. What will be the possible diagnosis?
A young male experiences skin discoloration after the start of drug therapy for leprosy. His skin color ranges from red-brown to black. Which of the following drugs causes this side effect?

A young male presents with painless profuse diarrhea. He is passing a large volume of stool flecked with mucus. He presents to the emergency response department dehydrated and in a state of shock. Which of the following is an appropriate statement if cholera is suspected?

answers.option: Hyperchlorhydria facilitates the passage of cholera bacilli into the small intestine
It releases GABA which is responsible for its secretory effect
Diarrhea occurs because of vibrio cholera invasive action
Cholera toxin releases 5-hydroxytryptamine from enterochromaffin cells in the gut

question: A young male, living in a non-malarious area, plans to visit an area where chloroquine-resistant Plasmodium falciparum is common. He is known to be intolerant to mefloquine and his glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) status is not known. Which of the following drugs will be prescribed to him for prophylaxis?

A young man presented to the emergency room with a history of high-grade fever associated with chills and rigors. He lives in an area of poor sanitation, streets with stagnant water, insects, and mosquitoes. A complete blood count (CBC) examination of blood from the patient revealed distorted RBCs, double in size, and Schüffner's dots. What is the causative agent?

A young man presents to the emergency department with a complaint of non-bloody diarrhea for the past 3 days. Stool culture is ordered. The culture reveals gram-negative rods with lactose fermenting colonies. Which of the following organisms is responsible for his symptoms?
A young patient presents with high-grade fever for 4 days and a generalized blanchable rash. What is the most appropriate diagnostic test for dengue at this stage?
According to Integrated Management of Neonatal & Childhood Illness (IMNCI), which of the following is the danger sign?
Ali and Ahmed get into a fight outside the school. Ali punches Ahmed hard enough to cause a fracture of the mandible along with the anterior dislocation. Which type of injury has Ali caused?
An 18-year-old boy with a fever and a vesicular rash for 2 days is admitted to the ward. With suspicion of chicken pox what necessary precautions should be taken to avoid exposing other patients?

answers.option: Single room isolation and droplet precautions
